title: Zhang Silai small class 69: how to train children to defecate regularly
body:
Defecation is not only a physiological need of people, but also controlled by people’s consciousness. When the baby’s awareness of defecation control has not yet occurred, physiological needs dominate. Defecation is a reflex activity. If the defecation reflex is often inhibited, it will gradually make the rectum lose its normal sensitivity to fecal pressure stimulation. Children around the age of 1 often neglect to excrete feces because of fun, so that the feces stay in the large intestine for too long, and the water in the feces is absorbed and becomes dry and hard. As a result, it is not easy to excrete, which is also one of the most common reasons for constipation. It is important to establish good defecation habits as soon as possible and develop the habit of regular defecation in the morning. It must be noted that children’s self-control awareness of defecation is formed earlier than that of urination.

After seven months, the child has learned to sit independently and sit more stably. Generally, children behave before defecation. They may suddenly turn red around their eyes, daze in their eyes, twist their body, turn their corners of their mouth to both sides, and even fart. At this time, you can practice your child’s defecation in the basin, and adults can hold him on one side. Once the child has defecated, he must be kissed to let the child gradually know that his parents like this defecation and feel comfortable. After that, every day, parents put their children on the bedpan to defecate at about the same time, and use language and expression to signal their children to defecate hard downward. A few weeks later, as soon as the child sits on the bedpan, his nervous system will produce a conditioned reflex and urge him to defecate hard downward, so as to form a good habit of defecating in the bedpan every day. After the age of 1, gradually train children to express their need to defecate in language. Such training will take some time. Parents should be patient. If properly trained, children can complete toilet training around the age of 2.

Try to arrange the time of defecation in the morning. The time of sitting in the basin each time should be about 5 minutes, not more than 10 minutes, so as not to cause the child’s disgust. After the child is 1 year old, you can buy a small toilet ring and put it on the adult’s big toilet ring to train the child to sit in the toilet and defecate. If parents train well and there is no special change in diet, children will defecate at a fixed time. Generally speaking, children can control their urine and urine well only at the age of 2 \~ 2.5.

title: Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge officially opened today: breaking the limit of Offshore Bridge Engineering
body:
After six years of preparation and nine years of construction, the Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge was officially opened. From scheme design to construction, China has created one by one, breaking the limit of the world’s Offshore Bridge Engineering.

The total length of the Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge is about 55 kilometers, of which the main works include 22.9 kilometers of bridges, 6.7 kilometers of subsea tunnels and east-west artificial islands connecting tunnels and bridges.

CCTV reporter Wu Jie: my current position is the dongrengong island of the Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge. Above my head are the dense takeoff and landing routes of the Hong Kong International Airport. Behind me is the busy golden waterway on Lingdingyang. Many bridge experts believe that it is almost an impossible task to link the core areas of Guangdong, Hong Kong and Macao and avoid affecting the sea and air transportation here.

In order to realize the non-interference of sea, land and air traffic, the Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge adopts the world’s first integrated scheme of bridge, island and tunnel. On the vast sea, engineers surrounded two artificial islands of 100000 square meters with 120 huge steel cylinders with a diameter of 22 meters and a height of 18 floors. The whole project took only 212 days.

The 6.7-kilometer-long subsea tunnel is composed of 33 large immersed tubes docked on the seabed. Each immersed tube weighs more than 80000 tons, which is equivalent to an aircraft carrier, and the accuracy of immersed tube docking should reach the centimeter level. These are unprecedented technological innovations in the history of bridge construction in the world

Su quanke, chief engineer of Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge Authority: bridges, tunnels and artificial islands are accurately manufactured in factories, and large-scale equipment is pulled over and installed. Therefore, the quality of this bridge is very high, which pushes China’s bridge construction to the level of industrial construction. We were very surprised that foreign experts could come to China to build bridges at this time.

In terms of the overall bridge design, the main bridge of Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge is largely constructed of prefabricated steel structure, with a total steel consumption of 420000 tons, which is enough to build ten bird nests. The exquisite construction technology makes the service life of the bridge up to 120 years, which is 20 years longer than the common design service life of sea crossing bridges in the world, and has become a new benchmark for bridge construction in the world.

Tan Guoshun, project manager of Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge project of China Railway Bridge Bureau: the requirements for the accuracy of each component are higher and higher. If the deviation is large, it can’t be installed. The requirement of 1 cm deviation (installation) proposed by Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge is unimaginable in the process of large-scale engineering construction in the world. The technical standard of Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge is much higher than that of any country in the world.

After the completion and opening of the Hong Kong Zhuhai Macao Bridge, the land transportation from Hong Kong to Zhuhai will be reduced from the previous three hours to 30 minutes. This super project on Lingdingyang will rewrite the economic territory of the Pearl River Delta and lay a solid foundation for the integration of Guangdong, Hong Kong and Macao.

title: New and old players compete to expand production. What is the hidden worry of lithium iron phosphate surplus?
body:
“In 2022, due to the shortage of raw materials, the arrival of overcapacity will be delayed to a certain extent. After 2023, with the gradual easing of the tight supply of lithium carbonate, the problem of overcapacity will be faced at that time.”

After nearly two years of rapid development, lithium iron phosphate cathode material seems to be sliding to the quagmire of overcapacity step by step.

According to Gaogong lithium battery, from January to March 2022 alone, there were 9 domestic projects involving lithium iron phosphate materials, with a planned capacity of 1.19 million tons. The chairman of a listed company of lithium battery cathode materials said, “our demand is at the level of millions of tons, while the supply starts at more than millions of tons.” The fund manager of a new energy industry in Shanghai also believes that “due to the large increase of production capacity, the capacity of lithium iron phosphate may be surplus in the second half of 2022.”

When will the situation of excess capacity of lithium iron phosphate appear? What impact will it have on the upstream and downstream enterprises of the industrial chain?

New and old players compete to expand production, and the planned production capacity far exceeds the demand

Benefiting from the rapid development of new energy vehicles and energy storage industry, China’s lithium iron phosphate battery shipment exceeded 160gwh in 2021, with a year-on-year increase of more than 150%; Lithium iron phosphate cathode material shipments 470000 tons, an increase of 277%.

Cinda Securities said that under the influence of the rapid rise of raw material prices and the decline of subsidies, the cost advantage of battery materials is highlighted. Lithium iron phosphate will continue its rapid growth trend in 2022. It is estimated that the global demand for lithium iron phosphate will reach 1.81 million tons by 2025.

However, according to the incomplete statistics of battery China, the expanded production scale of lithium iron phosphate announced by various manufacturers and the existing production capacity have exceeded 5 million tons, and the planned production capacity is significantly higher than the demand.

It is reported that the production expansion of lithium iron phosphate cathode materials mainly comes from three types of manufacturers:

1) Manufacturers whose main business is lithium iron phosphate, such as German nano (300769. SZ), Hunan Yuneng, etc.

2) Chemical enterprises with lithium iron phosphate business, such as Longbai group (002601. SZ), Chuanfa longmang (002312. SZ), etc.

3) The business is extended to the ternary material business of lithium iron phosphate, such as Changchang lithium (688779. SH), dangsheng Technology (300073. SZ), etc.

From the perspective of competition pattern, according to the data of Gaogong lithium battery, the market share of lithium ferrite material top5 in 2021 was 64%, down 19 percentage points from 2020 (83%). Among them, the total shipment proportion of top2 was 40%, down only 2 percentage points, and the market share of top3-5 was significantly reduced from 40% to 24%.

Cinda Securities believes that with the gradual release of new production capacity of chemical enterprises, the market concentration may continue to show a downward trend.

When the shortage of raw materials or delay the surplus time point, cost reduction PK is inevitable

In fact, behind the large-scale expansion of lithium iron phosphate material capacity, the shortage of raw materials is an indisputable fact.

In terms of lithium carbonate, according to the latest data released by the customs, the import volume of lithium carbonate in China in the first quarter of 2022 was 27497 tons, a year-on-year increase of 43.7%. Guojin Securities said that at present, the increment of the production end is quite limited, and there is still a shortage in 2022.

In terms of phosphate rock, since the second half of 2021, Yuntianhua, Wengfu group, kaiphosphorus group and some enterprises in Hubei have stopped selling or significantly reduced the take out volume of phosphate rock. At the same time, they have to purchase some medium and high-grade phosphate rock, resulting in less phosphate rock circulating in the market. At present, many phosphorus chemical enterprises reflect that it is very difficult to purchase phosphate rock.

In terms of iron phosphate, the expansion cycle is longer, 12-18 months, while the expansion cycle of lithium iron phosphate is 6-8 months. Therefore, the relative capacity of iron phosphate is lower in the short term.

“In 2022, due to the shortage of raw materials, the arrival of overcapacity will be delayed to a certain extent. After 2023, with the gradual easing of the tight supply of lithium carbonate, the problem of overcapacity will be faced at that time. Moreover, this is the overcapacity of the industry, and the profit margin of industry leaders will also be affected.” There are new industry analysts said.

A senior employee in the industry also believes that the problems of overcapacity superimposed on raw materials and cash flow will be gradually exposed. The road behind lithium iron phosphate is very difficult, and many small enterprises will be merged after 2023.

How will new and old players of lithium iron phosphate deal with the situation of overcapacity at that time?

First finance called German nano, Fulin Seiko and other enterprises. As of the press time, no reply has been received.

Xingfa group (600141. SH) said that after overcapacity in the future, the impact on the company depends on the cost, market price, product scale and other factors of manufacturing lithium iron phosphate.

The above-mentioned fund manager of Hushang new energy industry told China first finance and economics that the lithium iron phosphate processing link is surplus, the profit probability will be compressed, and all enterprises may usher in cost reduction PK. Enterprises with integrated layout have certain advantages. At the same time, with the decline of product prices, enterprises will have more or less pressure, followed by the exchange of quantity for price.

In fact, in order to reduce costs and increase efficiency, cathode material enterprises have expanded upstream and downstream. Taking German nano as an example, the company plans to invest 800 million yuan to build a 200000 ton / year lithium iron phosphate precursor project in Qujing, Yunnan, and cooperate with Ningde times and Yiwei lithium energy in the downstream. It is reported that the Defang Yiwei factory, which the company cooperates with Yiwei lithium energy, is the cathode material project with the largest monomer capacity in China.

Hunan Yuneng, Hubei Wanrun and anda technology have also announced the layout of iron phosphate business.

Chemical enterprises with cross-border layout are expected to give full play to their own advantages of integration. Such as iron source advantages of Longbai group, anada and other titanium dioxide enterprises; Phosphorus source advantages of phosphorus chemical enterprises such as Xingfa group and Yuntianhua.

It is worth mentioning that the overcapacity of lithium iron phosphate undoubtedly means an opportunity to improve profits for downstream power battery enterprises. Some people in the power battery industry said that if lithium iron phosphate has excess capacity, the cost will drop for battery enterprises. The above fund managers also believe that the overcapacity of lithium iron phosphate will benefit the power battery enterprises.

According to the data of China automotive power battery industry innovation alliance, the installed capacity of lithium iron phosphate batteries in China totaled 79.8gwh in 2021, accounting for 51.7%, which exceeded that of ternary batteries. In April 2022, the installed capacity of lithium iron phosphate power battery in China was 18.6gwh, with a year-on-year increase of 200.7%.

title: Four security personnel were killed when the Libyan court tried is members

title: Крипта для начинающих: сервисы и приложения
body:
Тут собраны сервисы и приложения, которые пригодятся вам при работе с криптой. Без некоторых обойтись невозможно, а с некоторыми просто удобно.

* Централизованные биржи
* Веб и мобильные кошельки
* Эксплореры (обзор транзакций и организация финансов)
* Децентрализованные финансы
* Полезные децентрализованные приложения

## Централизованные биржи

Пригодятся для обмена крипты на местную валюту и наоборот. Биржи контролируют ваши счета, поэтому не рекомендую долгосрочно хранить там крупные суммы, используйте биржи только при необходимости.

### OKX

[okx.com](https://www.okx.com/join/11514461) |

Основная биржа, которой пользуюсь я сам. Один из самых простых и удобных интерфейсов, которые мне попадались среди таких приложений, быстрая верификация, не блокируют и не ограничивают россиян.

Покупать или продавать крипту вы будете не с самой биржей, а с другими людьми, биржа предоставляет площадку и обеспечивает безопасность сделки.

По этой ссылке будет туториал по регистрации и использованию (появится позже)

### Binance

[binance.com](https://www.binance.com/) |

Одна из крупнейших в мире бирж, очень популярная, но, на мой взгляд не самая удобная. Может пригодиться для некоторых операций. Возможно позже сделаю туториал, если будет необходимость.

## Веб и мобильные кошельки

Подробнее о веб кошельках будет отдельный материал, а тут короткий список основных приложений и расширений, которыми я пользуюсь.

### MetaMask

[metamask.io](https://metamask.io/) |

MetaMask это расширение для браузера и мобильное приложение, которое позволяет создавать и управлять кошельки в сети Ethereum и подобных. Применяется в большинстве децентрализованых приложений, поэтому если собираетесь активно пользоваться криптой, то стоит установить и создать/добавить туда свой кошелек не связанный с биржей.

### Rainbow

[rainbow.me](https://rainbow.me/) |

Мобильный Ethereum кошелек с очень красивым и удобным интерфейсом, визуально приятнее чем MetaMask, но подойдет не во всех случаях, зато спасет, когда тупит MetaMask. В общем советую установить в качестве запасного.

## Эксплореры

Сервисы, которые позволяют просматривать ваши и чужие транзакции, удобно упорядочивают информацию об активах на вашем веб кошельке.

### Blockscan, Etherscan, Polygonscan и другие

[Blockscan](https://blockscan.com/) |

Введите адрес своего кошелька в поисковой строке и увидите ссылки на эксполреры для тех блокчейнов, где на вашем кошельке есть какие либо токены/операции, например:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/gU31JY1tUu6EnNwR_hgGF.png?height=696&width=1133)

Перейдем, например в PolygonScan, это эксплорер сети Polygon (MATIC), тут видно ваш баланс, какие токены на вашем кошельке и последние операции.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/1lczGBWKjJ7uqJM_JcPyQ.png?height=883&width=1816)

### DeBank

[debank.com](https://debank.com/) |

Сервис DeBank агрегирует информацию о ваших финансах и операциях и показывает вам в удобном виде, тут видно даже ваши вклады и займы в DeFi приложениях. Также вы можете подписываться на кошельки интересных вам людей, пытаться отслеживать их стратегии и тд.

## Децентрализованные финансы

При помощи этих приложений можно обменять одну крипту на другую или сделать вклад. В отличии от централизованных бирж не имеют контроля над вашим кошельком, а все операции выполняются при помощи смарт контрактов (программ), код которых при необходимости вы можете проверить.

**Для использования понадобится MetaMask или другой веб кошелек.**

### UniSwap, QuickSwap, Sushi

[uniswap.org](https://app.uniswap.org/) | [quickswap.exchange](https://quickswap.exchange/#/swap) | [sushi.com](https://app.sushi.com/)

Позволяют обменивать разные монеты в большом количестве блокчейнов (сетей), дают возможность вложиться в пулы ликвидности и получать проценты за вашу крипту, участвовать в кредитовании других пользователей. Выбирайте подходящий в зависимости от курса и наличия там интересного вам токена.

### SpookySwap

[spooky.fi](https://spooky.fi/) |

Основной DeFi сервис в сети Fantom, делает все то же, что и проекты перечисленные выше, но только в одной сети.

### PanCkakeSwap

[panckakeswap.finance](https://pancakeswap.finance/) |

Как и все вышеперечисленные проекты, но только для сети Binance Smart Chain

## Полезные децентрализованные приложения

Различные приложения, которые сэкономят ваше время, деньги и помогут в нестандартных ситуациях.

### stargate

[stargate.finance](https://stargate.finance/) |

stargate позволяет передать токен из одного блокчейна в другой с довольно низкой комиссией (в большинстве случаев) и довольно быстро.

Этот сервис пригодится вам в таких ситуациях: вы попросили клиента оплатить вам работу в USDT в сети Polygon, но клиент ошибся и отправил BUSD в сети Binance Smart Chain, а вы хотите отправить средства на OKX и обменять их на рубли. В таком случае можно зайти на stargate, перевести BUSD в USDT в сети Polygon и тогда отправить их на биржу.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wcWV8zXP9-kPvIS2cclwD.png?height=889&width=1871)

Пока это все, список будет пополняться по мере необходимости!

```
Если материал оказался для вас полезным,
можете отправить мне пару монет на кофе:
0x354d4D759c49094f60D537bfD7177c05b70c20cC
```

title: The UN Secretary General called on the international community to help the hurricane hit areas
body:
Xinhua news agency, United Nations, October 4 (reporter Shang Xuqian) - UN Secretary General Guterres called on the international community to give generously to help Caribbean countries hit by hurricanes. He also called on all countries to implement the Paris Agreement and actively respond to climate change.

Guterres will visit Antigua and Barbuda and Dominica this weekend to investigate the disaster situation in the two countries and study and judge the scale of United Nations Disaster relief assistance. When meeting reporters before his departure, he said that the United Nations had previously urged the international community to provide $113.9 million in emergency assistance to the affected countries in the Caribbean, but the response was not positive. Guterres called on the international community to respond positively in the coming weeks.

Guterres said that although people cannot link isolated weather events with climate change, scientists have found that the emergence of extreme weather is indeed related to climate change and will become the new normal after global warming.

He said that in the past 30 years, the number of weather related disasters has tripled every year, the economic losses have quadrupled, and the sea level has risen by 25 centimeters since 1870.

Guterres called on all countries to effectively implement their obligations under the Paris Agreement, believing that the Paris Agreement is an important step in addressing climate change and provides a solid foundation for future action. (end)

title: Toyota's first pure electric vehicle is listed in Japan for lease only
body:
Toyota will lease the bz4x sport utility vehicle (SUV) at a price equivalent to $39000 in the first four years. The agreement also includes insurance, maintenance costs and battery warranty costs. Customers will bear additional costs if they cancel the agreement in the first 48 months.

However, the move attracted the attention of analysts. According to industry data, the popularity of hybrid electric vehicles in Toyota’s Japanese market is still much higher than that of electric vehicles, which accounted for only 1% of passenger car sales in Japan last year. But overall, Japan’s electric vehicle market is still growing rapidly. Analysts said that the trend of electric vehicles in Japan will change soon, and Toyota may lose market share by focusing on leasing rather than purchase mode.

Toyota’s goal is to lease 5000 bz4xs in this fiscal year. The company plans to start selling bz4xs in other markets later this year. Some European countries have started booking, but have not decided on the time of sales in Japan.

Senior analysts at Tokai Tokyo Research Institute said that the popularity of electric vehicles in Europe is realized by leasing projects, and Toyota may be trying a similar strategy to promote it. Nevertheless, Japanese carmakers are still cautious about turning to all electric tracks, but in fact, Toyota pioneered hybrid vehicles as early as more than 20 years ago, and still maintains an ambitious development trend in hybrid vehicles and hydrogen vehicles.

title: Syrian HAMA province is armed forces cleared military: important progress
body:
Xinhua news agency, Damascus, October 4 (reporter Zheng Yihan and Che Hongliang) - the Syrian military said on the 4th that the government forces wiped out the armed forces of the Islamic state, an extremist organization entrenched in HAMA Province in central Syria, and made important progress in military operations.

Syrian military sources told Xinhua that government forces recovered more than 50 villages and towns in the eastern part of HAMA Province in the past month. With the removal of the last “Islamic state” stronghold, the government forces’ suppression operations in the region came to an end, and the “Islamic state” armed forces in the whole HAMA province were completely removed.

In late May this year, the Syrian government army launched a military operation codenamed “great dawn” to fight against the “Islamic state” on multiple fronts. Since early September, government forces have stepped up their crackdown on the “Islamic state” armed forces in the eastern part of HAMA province.

With the continuous progress of military operations, the main control area of the “Islamic state” in Syria has been compressed in the eastern province of deirzur. (end)

But it is certain that Greenland is not the first real estate enterprise for which Chen Zengli works. Before that, he was the assistant president of Zhongliang holding group, in charge of corporate financing, finance and investment.

In addition, Chen Zengli also worked in Southwest Securities, the “first A-share listed financial institution in Chongqing”, as the general manager of Zhejiang branch. He is very good at financial industry, investment banking and investment and financing business.

Greenland Hong Kong also has its own evaluation of the financial director who joined the company soon. According to the management member information of “Oriental fortune.com”, Chen Zengli has “many years of financial + industrial business management experience and has efficient financial and capital business control ability”.

Chen Zengli said six months ago that with the strengthening of the company’s overall operation control and external cooperation, the proportion of equity will be appropriately reduced, and the transformation of the proportion of land acquisition equity into the proportion of equity carried forward on the statement should lag by 2-3 years.

title: Mh370 final search report: spent $160 million to find only three fragments
body:
On October 3, after three years of search work, Australian Transport Safety Authority released the final summary report on Malaysia Airlines mh370 search in Sydney. Although the report did not explain the reason for the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight mh370, it mentioned that the scope of the crashed passenger plane may be found was reduced to 25000 square kilometers.

The report issued by the Australian Transport Safety Authority totaled more than 400 pages, recording in detail the efforts made by all parties to search for Malaysia Airlines mh370, especially the Australian led underwater search, including how to determine the search area and the specific situation of the search.

The process of searching for Malaysia Airlines mh370 can be called the largest action in aviation history. Later, submarine research, ocean current research and other technologies were used to reduce the most likely location of the aircraft to 25000 square kilometers.

The search lasted 1046 days, covering 120000 square kilometers of seabed area, with a total cost of 160 million US dollars. When the search operation was stopped in January this year, the whereabouts of the aircraft were not found except for three pieces of aircraft debris washed ashore along the coast of the Indian Ocean.

The release of the final search report of Malaysia Airlines mh370 means the official end of the search work led by Australia. However, the report also points out that the relevant investigation in Malaysia is still continuing.

title: Microsoft will launch new Microsoft adaptive accessories for disabled users to improve office efficiency
body:
Sina digital news on the afternoon of April 12, at the 12th Annual Microsoft capability summit, Microsoft announced the opening of a newly upgraded inclusive technology laboratory, added powerful software functions, and released Microsoft adaptive accessories to bring people with disabilities closer to technology.

In 2018, Microsoft launched the Xbox barrier free controller. The Xbox accessibility controller can meet the needs of gamers with limited mobility. It can be used with various external switches, brackets and joysticks to enable gamers to create controller settings to meet their specific needs.

Last fall, Microsoft also launched the surface adaptive suite, which is composed of a set of labels, indicators and openers to help visually impaired, visually impaired or disabled users customize the surface device, so as to facilitate their personal use.

In 2017, Microsoft opened a new inclusive technology laboratory, which is specially developed for the needs of all kinds of disabled people.

This time, Microsoft has launched a new Microsoft adaptive accessory, which provides a highly adaptive and easy to operate system, which can help people who are difficult to use traditional mouse and keyboard to create ideal settings, improve work efficiency, and use their favorite applications more effectively.

The traditional keyboard and mouse may have obstacles in use for people with mobility difficulties. These adaptive accessories can perform a variety of functions, reducing the pain points of users who have difficulty making full use of their PC.

Microsoft adaptive accessories have three main components, which can configure, 3D print and customize their own mouse, keyboard input and shortcuts according to our specific needs.

The first component is the Microsoft adaptive mouse, which can customize the mouse tail and thumb support accessories, or 3D print the mouse tail, so as to create a mouse that is really suitable for you. Microsoft adaptive mouse core, tail extension and thumb support accessories make up a lightweight and portable traditional mouse. In addition, the thumb support fitting can be adapted to both left-handed and right-handed people.

Next comes Microsoft adaptive accessories, including a central hub and new wireless buttons, which can replace or upgrade traditional keyboards. The Microsoft adaptive hub can be paired wirelessly with up to four Microsoft adaptive buttons to reduce line clutter while connecting multiple devices. The hub can also be used with standard 3.5mm auxiliary technology switches, and has three different configuration files, which can be used with multiple devices.

When paired with a Microsoft adaptive hub, the Microsoft adaptive button can be easily customized to become the preferred input device. You can also choose between d-pad, joystick or two button devices, use different button tops, or 3D print your own button tops according to specific needs. Whether you’re using a multi-functional two in one device like surface pro or any other windows PC, this wireless and multi-functional design can help you create the right setting scheme.

title: The F Word: Preventing the Fertility Freakout
body:
## 4 things to consider if you’re not thinking about kids yet but feel like you should be

by Erika Francks, Camille Berry, and Sujude Dalieh

*Content warning: Fertility is a sensitive topic and we absolutely do not want to push a “doomsday” outlook on it, but we strongly feel that knowledge is power in understanding your options and keeping them open.*

![We’ve all heard the phrase ‘your biological clock is ticking, we get it as a concept, we try not to let it stress us out because dating is damn hard and I’m focused on my career! and I have other shit to do too…but what’s cool now is there are other tools and options emerging. But in order to use them appropriately, we need to fully understand our biological limitations — not just as a vague concept. This graph made it real for us.](https://miro.medium.com/max/1310/0\*2QTq36S0vUpkR1C9)

Are you pretty sure you want kids but feel like *really* thinking about it is a “later you” problem? Have you heard about IVF or surrogacy and thought, “I should probably actually understand what that entails,” but never followed up? Do you get a little pit in your stomach when someone mentions egg freezing and think, “should I be looking into that?”

If any of these ring true for you, no worries, we are totally with you. It is completely normal to put off thinking about this stuff when it doesn’t feel particularly relevant or pressing! That said, we focused our [graduate thesis](https://soeithelp.stanford.edu/design-impact) research on enabling women to make informed decisions about their fertility and family planning. In interviewing dozens of women ages 21–40 over the past year, we’ve started to realize that pushing off thinking about this stuff is leading to what we now call “Oh Sh\*t” moments down the road, when suddenly options for having kids can feel a lot more limited and women ask themselves “when was I supposed to be planning for this?”

At the same time, women we interviewed who were not yet thinking about children reported feeling like they *should* be and asked us to share back with them what we found. There seems to be a general sense of “I should know more,” but not a lot of guidance on what to learn.

So, that said, we’re here to share a few things we’ve learned with you throughout our research so that we can all start clarifying our desires and understanding our options before we hit any sort of panic zone around fertility. This is in no way pushing anyone to have children, or to set hard-and-fast timelines, but just to help us all start having realistic conversations with ourselves around how our lives could play out, with a few guiding questions along the way.

## 1: The Disney Princess Complex and Preventing the “Oh Sh\*t” Moment

🔊[Listen as a podcast here](https://anchor.fm/thefwordfertility/episodes/The-Oh-Sht-Moment-e1ilpti)

## What is the “Disney princess” complex?

We’ll preface by pointing out that we didn’t come up with this term. It has been a headline before, but different groups have defined it in different ways. Some describe it as causing body image issues and an obsession with looks. Others (mostly male blogs) say it causes unrealistic expectations in dating. What *we* are calling the disney princess complex is the idea that we are socialized to believe once we fall in love, everything will fall into place in our lives and we’ll live happily ever after — a whimsical approach to dating and potential family-building.

Over the past few decades we’ve actually come a pretty long way in moving away from this narrative in how we think about relationships, since it’s obviously becoming more and more normal to be independent and career-focused and not just wait around for a man to save us. And beyond that, it’s way more accepted to be queer, not get married, or have different relationship structures like polyamory or open relationships.

But while narratives around what it means to be a woman in the world have shifted, our narratives around children have not. We’re still conditioned to believe that if we have a partner who loves us, kids will just work out when the time is right, like we see in fairytales. Or beyond fairytales, what we’ve seen with the generations before us. But as the “right time” for kids gets pushed due to later marriages, career aspirations, and financial constraints, for a lot of people it has become an experience far from a fairytale. The Disney princess influence on family “just working out” does not match our current reality, and provides a pretty unrealistic narrative of what to expect. We are not Disney princesses, nor do we want to be! But until we reconcile the disconnect and start planning within our current reality, “Oh Sh\*t” moments will continue to happen.

## What is causing these “Oh Sh\*t” moments and how can we prevent them?

## Need for reproductive assistance

One [statistic](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/pressroom/02news/ameriwomen.htm) to note is that the average age at which women had their first child in the US rose from 21.4 years old in 1970 to 26.9 in 2018. For fathers, it’s increased from 27 to 31. Obviously, this still sounds pretty young. I mean, we’re in our mid-twenties, but this age thing feeds into the fact that one in six couples today has trouble conceiving. And, in at least half of all cases of infertility, a [male factor](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/17201-male-infertility) is a major or contributing cause. So, often, the “Oh Sh\*t” moment in a heterosexual relationship could be getting to the point of being ready to have kids and then realizing you’re going to need some assistance if you want to have biological children–for queer couples this could be finding out how much it costs to utilize assisted reproductive technologies (ART) or realizing that you are not covered by insurance.

Author’s note: we believe everyone should have access to fertility benefits! And abortion! True agency is the ability to say no and to say yes (check out our website [http://whohateswomen.com](http://whohateswomen.com/) for more on this).

## Shift in life circumstances

Another reason for the “Oh Sh\*t” moment comes from life changes; we’ve heard from a lot of women in their 30’s or 40’s who went through breakups or encountered other life changes and suddenly their life circumstances around children were completely different. They’d been assuming things were going to work out when the time was right, and planning for a certain version of their life, but all of a sudden they’re asking themselves questions like, am I willing to have kids on my own? Should I have frozen my eggs years ago? How important are biological children to me?

## Medical diagnoses

And finally, “Oh Sh\*t” moments can come along with medical diagnoses. We have a really long way to go in the world of women’s healthcare to even understand what is going on with our bodies (we could do a whole separate book on that), but we’ve talked to a bunch of women who face an “Oh Sh\*t” moment when they suddenly become aware of a medical condition, like endometriosis, PCOS, or an autoimmune disease that could affect their fertility and need to make decisions about how to handle that. This can also come about at the moment of transition for transgender folks in deciding how to handle preserving fertility if they’d like to do so.

## What do I do with this information?

Right, so honestly, that’s kind of the whole point of this article! We know this stuff can be super overwhelming, and it’s way easier to just be like “I’ll deal with this later”. But we’ve heard from enough women now who kept moving the goalpost of “I’ll deal with this later,” and ultimately ended up in very stressful scenarios, that we really think there is value in starting to think about this stuff earlier on.

For a lot of people, this is honestly just getting clear with yourself on some possible scenarios for how your life could play out and thinking through what you might do in that situation. Here are some examples:

“I know I *really* want kids, so if I get to be in my early 30’s and I’m still really not feeling ready, maybe that’s when I get a fertility assessment to see if anything is abnormal that I should be aware of?”

“I’m not sure if I want kids yet, but if I decide to have them it would likely be in my late 30’s or even early 40’s, thus IVF could be necessary. Maybe I could consider freezing my eggs at a younger age in order for that to have a higher chance of success?”

“I’m queer and know I will want to use assited reproductive technologies to have children, but all of that can cost a lot of money. Maybe I could start saving or advocating for fertility benefits in my workplace?”

Again, none of this is personal or medical advice at all, but we think knowledge is power. If we can get educated on the options out there, understand the realistic costs and limitations that might exist, and reflect on how these options might fit into our own lives, then we have a lot more agency over our futures. We can avoid the “Oh Sh\*t” moments, not miss out on options because we didn’t know or didn’t understand, and feel convicted in our decisions when it is time to make them.

## 2: The Paradox of Partnership

🔊[Listen as a podcast here](https://anchor.fm/thefwordfertility/episodes/The-Paradox-of-Partnership-e1ilpvg)

## What is the “Paradox of Partnership?”

When chatting with dozens of women between the ages of 21 and 40, partnership and lack of partnership are both used as reasons to delay thinking about family planning and fertility. We heard people in partnerships say “I’m not too worried about it, we’ll have these conversations once we get more serious about having kids” and people without partners say “I don’t have a partner so I don’t think about family planning yet.” Sound like you?

## So, when are people planning for children?

In many cases, right before they start trying! Which, in our parents’ generation, made a bit more sense because marriage and children were essentially the default for everyone and timelines tended to move more quickly. Now, couples are waiting a lot longer not only to marry, but also to have kids. Many factors contribute to this, but according to [a study](https://modernfertility.com/modern-state-fertility-2020-sofi-career-money) by Sofi and Modern Fertility, 60% of respondents reported delaying childbearing due to not having enough money. Life costs more money nowadays, so getting to a place where we can fully provide for children is taking longer than for our parents, and we have pretty abysmal childcare support in this country to help us.

On top of that, there are higher numbers of women pursuing education and continued education, and more women working and advancing in their careers. Relationships and dating have changed, as well–in some ways it feels like we’re all slight commitment-phobes due to the rise of divorce rates we experienced with our parents’ generation.

So, all of this combined is pushing out the timeline for having kids. Which in some sense is awesome. It provides more opportunity to pursue other things outside of building a family. The only problem is that our ability to have biological children really does change over time. We can push out the timeline, but if the goalpost keeps moving back and back and back, eventually we could run into a situation where we just don’t have as many options as we did before. Most folks we’ve interviewed have pretty vague ideas of what it might look like to try to have kids at different stages of life given egg counts, fertility challenges, etc.

Hence, the need to plan ahead. We believe more forethought could go into what you want, outside of partnership. When you consider divorce rates averaging around 45–50%, the likelihood of raising children on your own or co-parenting from different households is actually quite high. This is not a fun statistic, but it was a reframe that helped us think through the realities of choosing to have children.

We also heard many stories of women experiencing a breakup at 35, 36, 37 with someone they thought they were going to marry and have kids with. That can’t be planned for, of course, but it’s a very real possibility–partnership is kind of a question mark! Doesn’t it feel a bit odd to hinge such a big decision on a question mark?

## Yes! What do I do with this information?

We plan out almost everything else in our lives, so it’s interesting that we keep this sort of whimsical outlook of “it will fall into place!” Or “if it’s meant to be it will be” around having kids. We believe this is a conversation that is useful to have with ourselves, outside of partnership, so that we can handle possible changes in our lives with the grounding that we know what we want.

We’ve laid out some examples of guiding questions to think about with yourself, whether or not you have a partner:

“I don’t have a partner at this moment and I’m like 75% sure I want kids in the future, but definitely not 100%…would I be willing to spend money on getting a fertility assessment or freezing my eggs now so that I can have some extra buffer room to decide?”

“I definitely need to be on the same page about kids as my partner before marriage, but when I brought it up it kind of caught them off-guard. What do I really want kid-wise and what kind of timeline am I thinking about? What will I do if we don’t align?”

“Thinking about future partners — I’d want to ask myself if I would feel confident raising a child with them if we did not stay together romantically in the future?”

“What if I’m not even sure I want the 1:1 partnership model for the rest of my life? Would I consider having kids on my own? Would I want to be a “choice mom” (the new term for having children solo intentionally)?

“Do I want multiple partners or a larger family unit to raise children with as a community?”

Now, this is not to scare anyone or push folks to overplan. These are huge questions, and our answers can change over time. But knowing our options, being real about the various outcomes that could play out, and having a good sense of our own desires–detached from partnership–should set us up to have much more agency than if we put off thinking about children until we want to start trying.

## 3: False Confidence in Options and Fertility Unit Economics

🔊[Listen as a podcast here](https://anchor.fm/thefwordfertility/episodes/False-Optionality-e1ilq0l)

## What is causing “false confidence” in fertility?

With rapid advancements in fertility technology and heavy investment in the space, it’s easy to believe that we will have plenty of options for conceiving when the time is right. There are some really exciting emerging technologies. However, due to high cost and mixed success rates of fertility interventions, our current options are actually less of a slam dunk than we think, and can lead to emotional and physical challenges.

We also seem to have a skewed understanding of the accessibility of these fertility interventions, partly from the influence of celebrity news and social media. In 2015, Gabrielle Union opened up about the shame she felt in prioritizing career over family building, leading her to pursue IVF in her 40’s. In 2016, Selena Gomez froze her eggs; her medical care team recommended considering the procedure before undergoing chemotherapy for Lupus. In 2018, Halsey froze her eggs at 23 due to her endometriosis diagnosis and related surgeries. In 2020, we learned more about Kim Kardashian’s fertility journey–during her first two pregnancies she experienced placenta accreta and gestational diabetes, a condition in which the placenta gets stuck inside the body during birth. Because of this, she chose to use surrogates for her third and fourth children. In 2021, we watched Heather Rae from Selling Sunsets document her fertility journey through IVF and embryo preservation on TikTok. And finally, in 2022, we learned Chrissy Teigen is using IVF to try for her third child and saw her share the all-too-common, but often private, pain of miscarriage.

On the one hand, this exposure is great. It’s passively trojan-horsing some of this fertility information to folks and normalizing conversations. But while exposure is good, it could also be giving us a false sense of security. We hear the ages of some of these celebrities and think “ah, I have all the time in the world.” However, for them, money isn’t an issue. They can afford as many cycles or procedures as it takes, and can seek out and travel to the best clinics in the world.

We also detected a lot of false confidence when speaking with women who use their mom’s story as an example of success. We heard things like, “well my mom had a kid at 39, so I’m probably good!” However, there are differences between our mothers’ generation and ours. Not only are we, on average, having kids later in life, there’s also more and more [evidence ](https://www.popsci.com/air-pollution-fertility-pregnancy/)that environmental factors like pollution affect fertility, and that fertility is generally on the decline.

Fertility struggles also are not limited to women. In fact, it’s a giant misconception and one that we need to set straight. In at least half of all cases of infertility, a male factor is a [major or contributing cause](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/17201-male-infertility). While researchers aren’t sure what exactly is causing male-factor infertility–they mostly blame environmental factors–it is clear that male fertility is decreasing. In 1992, a [study](https://www.bmj.com/content/305/6854/609) found a global 50% decline in sperm counts in men over the previous 60 years. Multiple studies over subsequent years confirmed that initial finding, including a 2017 [paper](https://academic.oup.com/humupd/article/23/6/646/4035689) showing 50–60% decline in sperm concentration between 1973 and 2011 in men from around the world.

So what does this mean? We’re not trying to scare the shit out of everyone. But there’s no denying fertility is changing and the need for assisted reproductive technologies is increasing. We need to get real about how much different treatments cost and the likely success rates at different ages (because age matters here too) with assisted reproductive technologies like IUI, egg freezing, and IVF. With this information we can better plan, better save, and better prioritize when making life decisions, like potentially taking fertility benefits into account when job searching.

## How much do fertility options really cost?

To begin, we need to make clear that most of these procedures are not covered by insurance, public or private. This is something not everyone knows. Unless it is deemed “medically necessary,” like in the case of women undergoing chemotherapy for cancer, it is not covered. And these guidelines are quite strict–we spoke with a woman undergoing chemo for an autoimmune disease who could not get egg freezing covered as “medically necessary” because it wasn’t cancer. This also typically excludes LGBTQ+ individuals who don’t meet the definitions of “infertility” that may qualify them for coverage. Even transgender individuals undergoing gender-affirming care may not meet the criteria for “infertility” that would cover them for fertility preservation (think: egg or sperm freezing).

So, most patients are paying out of pocket for these treatments, which can end up being well over $10,000, depending on the treatment. Let’s break it down. And shoutout to [FertilityIQ](https://www.fertilityiq.com/) — a super informative fertility education site that helped us source these numbers (this platform also costs money…nothing is free in this fertility world!).

## IUI

IUI, which stands for Intrauterine Insemination, is a procedure to put sperm directly inside the uterus, helping healthy sperm get closer to an egg. It is usually a “first try” for unexplained infertility. You may explore this if you have endometriosis or low sperm count/quality. It would also be used for same-sex female couples using donor sperm, or single women using donor sperm. It averages between $500-$4000 per cycle or “try,” essentially. The range is so wide because it can vary by medication pricing, monitoring and bloodwork, and the insemination procedure, so it mostly depends on the clinic you go to.

## IVF

IVF, which stands for In-Vitro Fertilization, is a procedure in which eggs and sperm are fertilized outside of the body in a test tube or petri dish, and then a viable fertilized embryo is put directly inside the uterus. It can be eggs and sperm from partners, or donor eggs / donor sperm. It is also often used with surrogates. This is often a next step in the unexplained infertility process, or for women who have fallopian tube damage/blockage, or other health concerns. IVF can cost well over $20,000 for one cycle when tallying the cost of treatment and medication–most women will average 2.1 cycles, bringing the total cost upwards of $40,000. Cost also depends on if you do genetic testing or other add-ons and is variable by clinic and by state.

## Egg freezing

Egg freezing is the last one we’ll cover, although there are many more fertility options. Egg freezing is a procedure in which eggs are extracted and then frozen using cryopreservation. It is used as a preservation measure, so that you can use the eggs later. You can freeze embryos (fertilized eggs) for preservation as well. On average, egg freezing patients will spend $30,000-$40,000 on treatment and storage. The breakdown is around $15,000 per cycle (to extract the eggs) and most women do an average of 2.1 cycles. Storage costs depend on location, but average around $500 per year.

It becomes even more complex when assessing the unit economics of fertility treatments. Freezing your eggs at 32 is a very different financial decision than freezing your eggs at 38, or 43 like Kourtney Kardashian. For example, you might be able to get 40 eggs in one round at age 32 for $20,000 with longer-term storage costs, and 20 eggs in three rounds at age 38 for $60,000 with reduced storage costs. We should be thinking not only about which fertility options might make sense for us, but also when those options make sense in the context of our wants and needs. It’s not fun to have to think about unit economics when thinking about the magic of having a baby! But that is exactly the kind of psychological barrier we hope to help women overcome.

## So, what could I be thinking about?

There are a few companies popping up to make fertility procedures cheaper, which is exciting. That’s essentially [Kindbody’s](https://kindbody.com/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=cpc&utm_campaign=kindbody&utm_term=kindbody&utm_campaign=__Kindbody+Brand&utm_source=adwords&utm_medium=ppc&hsa_acc=5349304425&hsa_cam=15158927904&hsa_grp=132895691881&hsa_ad=558827162131&hsa_src=g&hsa_tgt=kwd-482671827007&hsa_kw=kindbody&hsa_mt=p&hsa_net=adwords&hsa_ver=3&gclid=Cj0KCQjwspKUBhCvARIsAB2IYutVqaW_myuSzBGeZxOcosPqZGy-GuI_1dUAym-32IhnsXPZIIu6lHUaArX5EALw_wcB) premise–they’re improving user experience but also trying to drive down costs. But even at Kindbody, if you want to get a basic fertility assessment to find out where you’re at and if you should be worried, it can still be upwards of $300. In some states, insurance companies are required to cover a fertility assessment, so if you’re interested in getting a fertility workup done, talk to your OBGYN. They should be able to refer you to a clinic, and with that referral your insurance could cover it. But *always* ask upfront what your insurance will cover.

There are also companies like [Carrot Fertility](https://www.get-carrot.com/) or [Progyny](https://progyny.com/) that facilitate employers offering their employees fertility benefits. You could consider negotiating or advocating for fertility benefits in your current company or next job! And finally, there are companies like [Sunfish](https://joinsunfish.com/) offering financing and loans for fertility treatments.

Additionally, here are a few guiding questions you could ask yourself:

“How do I feel about assisted reproductive technologies in general?”

“Do I know what, if any, fertility coverage I currently have?”

“If I have a partner(s), have we mutually discussed our feelings about ART? Does my partner have fertility benefits?”

“I’m queer and would likely use ART to have a biological child with my partner, how might we plan for that?”

“If I’m diagnosed with a fertility issue (about 10% of women have PCOS and 2–10% have endometriosis) and struggle to get pregnant naturally, how much money, if any, would I be willing to spend on assisted reproductive technology?”

“Am I willing to start saving money (or advocating for benefits!) now to have a plan in place for if I might need ART?”

## 4: Why We Might Not Want Kids

🔊[Listen as a podcast here](https://anchor.fm/thefwordfertility/episodes/Why-We-Might-Not-Want-Kids-e1ilq28)

## Let’s talk about this!

Obviously, it’s becoming increasingly socially acceptable to not want kids, but we don’t actually spend much structured time thinking or talking about the reasons why we do or do not want kids. We found in many cases in our interviews with women, it’s just referred to as a feeling. But where does this feeling come from? Is it subliminal social pressure? What your friends are doing? The next logical step in your relationship with your partner? Or, is it truly your own desire and intentional decision, one way or another?

So, let’s talk about why we might not want kids! Lack of a supportive partner, lifestyle and identity, climate change, and health concerns are all valid reasons for choosing not to have children and deserve some discussion to spark thoughtful reflection. And, even without children of your own, there are many ways to integrate children into your life if you still want to be around them.

## Lack of supportive partner

Unfortunately, the ever-present influence of traditional gender roles feeds into considerations around lack of a supportive partner. According to [happiness](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/happiness) expert Paul Dolan, a professor of behavioral science at the London School of Economics, women who are single with no children are actually the happiest. Dolan [explains](https://www.businessinsider.com/unmarried-childless-women-are-happiest-expert-says-2019-5) that while men derive benefits from [marriage](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/marriage), the same cannot generally be said for women. This statement is clearly very heteronormative and sweeping, and there are many really great marriages out there, but women are still typically the default for emotional and household labor within marriages, which gets exacerbated with children involved. Married heterosexual mothers notoriously take on more responsibilities than their male partners and very different responsibilities than their single women counterparts.

## Lifestyle and identity

Here, we want to touch on the concept of “regretting motherhood” which is super taboo in our society to talk about.

Sociologist Orna Donath published a book called [Regretting Motherhood,](https://www.goodreads.com/en/book/show/32302223-regretting-motherhood) which is a study on women who self-report regretting becoming mothers. There are many different reasons they became mothers in the first place–avoiding divorce, meeting family expectations, fitting in with friends, or simply because they thought it was the “next step”–and some of them actually did have a strong desire to be mothers before having kids, but all of them ended up regretting it when faced with the reality of motherhood.

We always hear about women who choose *not* to be mothers being warned that they will regret their decision later in life, but we really don’t talk about the possibility that the opposite could also be true — that a woman who becomes a mother might regret it. This brings us back to women dealing with most of the emotional and household labor in heterosexual relationships–the burden of childbearing often does fall primarily on the woman, which is a very real factor to consider depending on your relationship. Looking at the realities of the lifestyle changes and identity changes that come along with having kids, you might just decide you are not down for that shift and really value your autonomy, which is a completely valid choice.

## Climate change

Climate change is a very real consideration for a lot of folks in the decision of whether or not to have kids. In our parents’ generation, they still had plenty of societal issues going on that could make them wary of bringing children into the world (ex. war, economic stress, etc.), but it wasn’t at quite the same level of climate change–our world is fully on fire and not on track to stabilize.

Given the trajectory we’re on, there’s definitely questions of: “What kind of world am I bringing my kids into?” “Where should we live so that we’re not at constant threat of floods, fires, famine, etc., and can we even afford that?” For some, this feels more pressing than for others, but certainly we’re hearing more and more about people choosing not to have children due to climate change.

We are absolutely not trying to be doomsday here, and there’s an argument on the flip-side of all this where having children is actually a sign of sustained hope for the world, but we just want to validate the fact that you might have considered this and that you are not crazy for factoring climate into your decision-making.

## Health concerns

Finally, health concerns are a valid consideration. Maybe you are already dealing with a health condition that meaningfully affects your life and you do not know how a pregnancy or the stress of having children might impact your own personal health. We spoke with a woman who has a very intense autoimmune disease and is worried about taking care of a child while also trying to manage her disease. Obviously, our society should have better resources for and access to childcare, which would solve many of these problems, but within our current reality this is a serious consideration.

Even the act of giving birth can come with serious health risks that are rarely talked about. [303,000](https://everymothercounts.org/our-story/the-issue/?gclid=Cj0KCQjwspKUBhCvARIsAB2IYuucoFuxdQwdJE4OyzDt4eGzFYrpU5MOFsJEDNZWagVR3FhDXp6sFzwaAhVzEALw_wcB) women die around the world as a result of complications of pregnancy and childbirth every year, and due to inequitable care, Black Women in the US have the highest [maternal mortality rate](https://usafacts.org/articles/the-us-maternal-mortality-rate-peaked-during-the-pandemic-and-was-highest-for-black-women/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=cpc&utm_campaign=ND-Healthcare&gclid=Cj0KCQjwspKUBhCvARIsAB2IYutgrWUncb-QfJGc1JhdkS2mNZQbTxcO2t3O1wry1n1lTQJxH4B1d64aAp-VEALw_wcB), more than two times worse than that of any other racial or ethnic group.

Additionally, we are not told much about birthing until it happens to us. Even with more and more women opening up about the realities of childbirth on social media, we are still wildly uninformed when it comes to what happens to our bodies during and after childbirth. Even miscarriages are taboo, yet 10–20% of known pregnancies end in them. For some women, this might have a meaningful impact on whether or not they want to be a birthing parent and thus it should not remain a taboo topic.

## What can I be thinking about?

So, there are a lot of reasons you might not want kids. We have a really strong narrative in society that parenthood will be the best thing that ever happened to you. However, we heard a quote recently that we loved along the lines of, “We are told parenthood will be the best thing that ever happened to you, but if you don’t become a parent or don’t want to,\* something else \*will be the best thing that ever happened to you.” You’ll always have a best thing! The best thing is not the same for everyone.

The status quo and cultural expectation is still to have children, but women are still sacrificing the most with having kids. So we hope that the decision of whether or not to have kids becomes more intentional– one you truly have conviction in. Also, experiencing the positive impacts of “nurturing” something does not have to be children. It could be nurturing your relationships, your community, the world in whatever way feels right to you. Or, if you are really inclined to nurture children, there are a million ways to integrate kids into your life even if they are not your own.

Here are some guiding questions to consider:

“Have I thought about all the ways my lifestyle would change if I were to have kids? Am I okay with that? “

“Do I want kids of my own or just kids in my life in general?”

“Do I feel like I would be taking on the role of primary caregiver in my relationship if we were to have kids, and if so, am I okay with that?”

“Do I feel that bringing a child into the world is something I’m comfortable with given my own personal feelings about the trajectory our world is on?”

“Does having the right partner meaningfully impact whether or not I would want kids?”

## Final thoughts

Ultimately, the goal of this article is to help women avoid the “Oh Sh\*t” moment we keep hearing about, where they get totally blindsided by fertility challenges. And again, you can have babies at any age and in a lot of different ways–we just want everyone to understand the options that are available to them and empower everyone to become their own advocate!

## Please reach out if this brought anything up for you or if you have any questions!

title: Ministry of ecology and environment: by 2025, the national rural domestic sewage treatment rate will reach 40%
body:
Ministry of ecology and environment: by 2025, the national rural domestic sewage treatment rate will reach 40%

The Ministry of ecology and environment recently held a regular press conference in April. Su kejing, director of the Department of soil ecological environment of the Ministry of ecological environment, said that he would deeply fight the tough battle of agricultural and rural pollution control, give full play to the role of the government, the market and villagers, and speed up the filling of weaknesses. By 2025, the national rural domestic sewage treatment rate will reach 40%.

Su kejing said that in recent years, the Ministry of ecological environment, together with relevant departments, has formulated plans according to local conditions, popularized typical experience and practices, accelerated the establishment of rural domestic sewage treatment system, and achieved preliminary results. “But on the whole, the foundation of rural domestic sewage treatment is weak and the task is still arduous. By 2021, the rural domestic sewage treatment rate is only about 28%.” In this regard, the Ministry of ecology and environment will further fight the tough battle of agricultural and rural pollution control and speed up the filling of weaknesses. By 2025, the national rural domestic sewage treatment rate will reach 40%.

First, give play to the leading role of local governments. Strengthen the overall connection, take the county as the unit, comprehensively manage the rural domestic sewage, and organically connect with toilet improvement, urban development, rural construction, land and space planning, etc.

Second, give play to the main role of the market. Follow the economic law, let the main body, projects, funds and other elements live, and operate in a market-oriented and sustainable manner. Qualified areas can entrust professional institutions to comprehensively implement rural domestic sewage treatment and improve the level of large-scale operation.

Third, give full play to the role of villagers’ participation. Fully respect the farmers’ rights to know, participate and supervise, and enhance their sense of ownership. Give full play to the organization and coordination role of the two village committees, and organize villagers to participate in sewage treatment planning, construction, operation and management through fund-raising and labor raising, so as to get through the “last kilometer”.
